summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan granting a short continuance of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial from July 2021 to fall 2021. The continuance is granted due to the government's filing of a superseding indictment (S2) which added new charges and an alleged victim, requiring additional defense preparation. The order balances the defense's need for time against the interests of justice and the public's interest in a timely trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose defense counsel requested a continuance of the trial date due to a new superseding indictment.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge who issued the order granting a short continuance of Maxwell's trial to fall 2021.

persons.name: Judge Furman
persons.context: A judge presiding over a separate criminal matter involving lawyers who also represent Maxwell, leading to a scheduling conflict mentioned in the order.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell and issued the order regarding her trial schedule.

events.title: Filing of S2 Superseding Indictment
events.description: The Government filed an S2 Superseding Indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell, adding new charges and extending the timeframe of alleged conspiracies.

events.title: Originally Scheduled Trial Start
events.description: The trial in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell was originally scheduled to commence on this date.

events.title: Deadline for Joint Trial Date Proposal
events.description: The parties are ordered to meet and confer and jointly propose a new trial start date for fall 2021 by this date.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court granted Ghislaine Maxwell's request for a continuance, moving her trial from July 12, 2021, to fall 2021.
The continuance was necessitated by a superseding indictment (S2) filed on March 29, 2021, which added new charges and identified a fourth alleged victim (Minor Victim-4).
The new indictment extended the timeframe of the alleged conspiracies from through 1997 to 2004 and added charges for sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of a minor.
The court cited the COVID-19 pandemic as a factor hampering trial preparation due to travel constraints and safety concerns.
The order emphasizes balancing the defense's need for preparation time against the public's interest in a trial without undue delay.
